sen.e: Immediately after the Heiji War, he captured FUJIWARA no Tsunemune and FUJIWARA no Korekata, close associates of Emperor Nijo, on the order of Kiyomori, according to "Gukansho" (Jottings of a Fool).

sen.j: 忠清は平氏一門の中でも特に平重盛に近仕していて、平維盛の乳父（めのと）の立場にあった。
sen.e: Among the Taira family, Tadakiyo was especially close to TAIRA no Shigemori, and was a menoto (foster father) of TAIRA no Koremori.

sen.j: 広常の態度は「志ヲ尽シ思ヲ運テ賞玩シ愛養スル事甚シ」かったという（『源平盛衰記』）。
sen.e: "Genpei Seisui ki" (Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and the Taira clans) describes Hirotsune's attitude as 'full of good will with a great abundance of appreciation.'

sen.j: 治承三年の政変（1179年）で忠清は、解官された藤原為保に代わり上総介となり、従五位下に叙せられた。
sen.e: At the Coup of the Third Year of Jisho in 1179, he became Kazusa no suke (Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province) in place of FUJIWARA no Tameyasu, who had been dismissed, and was also appointed as Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: その際に、「坂東八カ国の侍の別当」（『平家物語』）として東国の武士団を統率する権限も与えられたらしい。
sen.e: In addition, he was given authority to lead the bushidan (warrior bands) in the eastern countries as 'betto (administrator) of samurai in the Bando eight countries,' according to "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike).

sen.e: In later years, Yoshimori WADA wished for Tadakiyo's position as betto for a reward, and was appointed as Samuraidokoro Betto (administrator of the Board of Retainers) of the Kamakura government.

sen.j: 上総の国衙を掌握した忠清は、広常に対して恩を忘れた強圧的な態度に転じ、陳弁のため上洛した広常の子・能常を拘禁する。
sen.e: After taking control of kokuga (provincial government office compounds) in Kasuga Province, Tadakiyo forgot Hirotsune's favor and took up a high-handed attitude and detained Yoshitsune, son of Hirotsune, who was visiting Kyoto for pleading.

sen.j: 忠清の圧迫に怒った広常は、やがて平氏に反旗を翻すことになる。
sen.e: Angered at Tadakiyo's oppression, Hirotsune eventually rebelled against the Taira clan.

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）5月の以仁王の挙兵では、弟・景家や嫡子・忠綱とともに以仁王を追撃する。
sen.e: At the Rising of Prince Mochihito in May, 1180, Tadakiyo chased Prince Mochihito with his brothr Kageie and his legitimate son Tadatsuna.

sen.j: 宇治川では馬筏（いかだ）を組んで渡河を決行、源頼政らを討ち取った。

sen.e: Informed that Prince Mochihito had taken refuge in Nara and that it was uncertain whether he was dead or alive, TAIRA no Shigehira and Koremori attempted to invade Nanto, or Nara, but Tadakiyo stopped them, saying, 'thought is needed as to heading for Nanto in the evening: the young never know the details of military operations,' according to "Sankaiki," a diary of Tadachika NAKAYAMA.

sen.e: The eastern countries were thrown into turmoil when Yoritomo raised an army in September, and the imperial decree to search and kill Minamoto no Yoritomo was issued throughout the Tokaido countries.

sen.j: 22日、追討使として維盛が軍を率いて福原を進発すると、忠清は侍大将として付き従った。
sen.e: On September 22, Koremori left Fukuhara to lead the army as an envoy to search and kill Yoritomo as Tadakiyo accompanied him as a samurai daisho (warrior who gave orders at batteles).

sen.j: 10月18日、追討軍は駿河国に達して富士川で反乱軍と対峙するが、数万の敵兵に対して官軍はわずか千騎という有様で、忠清は形勢不利と判断して維盛に撤退を進言する。
sen.e: On October 18, the government army arrived at Suruga Province and confronted the rebel at Fuji-gawa River, where an army of one thousand soldiers faced a couple of ten thousand enemy soldiers, and Tadakiyo figured he was losing ground, proposing to Koremori to draw off.

On October 18, the government army arrived at Suruga Province and confronted the rebel at Fuji-gawa River, where an army of one thousand soldiers faced several tens of thousands of enemy soldiers, and Tadakiyo figured he was losing ground, proposing to Koremori to draw off.

sen.j: 忠清は「次第の理を立て、再三教訓」して、撤退を渋る維盛を説得したという（『玉葉』）。
sen.e: Tadakiyo 'gave logical explanations and repeatedly taught lessons' to persuade Koremori, who was hesitant to retreat, according to "Gyokuyo" a diary of Kanezane KUJO.

sen.j: 寿永2年（1183年）7月の平氏の都落ちには出家して同行せず、畿内にとどまって源義仲との和睦を図るなど独自の動きを見せる（『玉葉』）。
sen.e: Tadakiyo, who was in priesthood by then, did not accompany the Taira clan when they fled Kyoto in July, 1183, and stayed in the Kinal region as he tried to reconcile with MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka in his own way, according to "Gyokuyo."

sen.j: 一ノ谷の戦いが終結した後の元暦元年（1184年）7月、忠清は平家継とともに平氏の本拠地の伊賀国・伊勢国で大規模な反乱（三日平氏の乱 (平安時代)）を起こした。
sen.e: In July, 1884, after the end of the Battle of Ichinotani, Tadakiyo waged a large-scale revolt, called Mikka Heishi no ran (the three-day rebellion by the Taira clan), with TAIRA no Ietsugu in their home ground of Iga and Ise Provinces.

sen.e: When MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune stared off to attack Yashima the following year, Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa tried to stop him in fear of Tadakiyo' s threat; this reveals how powerful Tadakiyo was.

sen.j: 平氏一門が壇ノ浦の戦いで滅亡した後の5月、忠清は志摩国麻生浦で加藤光員の郎等に捕らえられ、16日六条河原で処刑された（『吾妻鏡』）。
sen.e: In May, 1185, after the Taira clan died out at the Battle of Danno-ura, Tadakiyo was captured by Mitsukazu KATO's followers in Ounoura, Shima Province, and was executed in the Rokujo-gawara riverbed on May 16, according to "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East).

In May, 1185, after the Taira clan died out at the Battle of Danno-ura, Tadakiyo was captured by Mitsukazu KATO's followers in Onoura, Shima Province, and was executed in the Rokujo-gawara riverside on May 16, according to "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East).
